reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 12, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Beautiful descriptions of the Gilded Age.
reviews.reviewText: Watching the series The Gilded Age left me wanting more as I waited for the next episode to drop. I found Gilded Summers and thoroughly enjoyed it.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 11, 2023
reviews.reviewText: Enjoyed the way the chapters were about first one and then the other main characters. Will read the next book also.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 10, 2019
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars GILDED SUMMERS: a journey to America's past, masterfully woven by Donna Russo Morin
reviews.reviewText: If you are already a fan of Donna Russo Morin’s award-winning historical fiction, then you know you’re in for a treat with Gilded Summers. As with her other historical fiction, such as her trilogy Da Vinci’s Disciples, we are shown the past through the flesh and blood characters’ lives and stories. We immediately become immersed in their time and place—their lives are real lives, like our own. While Russo Morin’s research is impeccable, it does not distract but enhances our immersion. In Gilded Summers, two girls become women together even though they are forbidden the intense friendship they conceive and defend. Pearl is the daughter of members of Gilded Age society, a family so vastly rich that they own two mansions: one in the “cottage” neighborhood of Newport, RI, and one in Manhattan. Ginerva is an Italian immigrant newly arrived in America, a girl who must serve Pearl’s family and Pearl herself. Pearl struggles to fulfill her longing to become an artist—a goal forbidden by her social-climbing mother. The talented, hardworking Ginerva designs clothes and dreams of earning her living as a fashion designer—a goal kept out of reach by her low status, sex, and lack of education. The girls help one another keep their dreams alive as they grow into womanhood. Enter two young men—both society gentlemen—attractive to the young women, one corruptly attracted to both young women. The events that follow have the power to shatter the women’s lives, let alone their friendship. The women’s actions, mistakes, and feelings are relatable as they struggle to survive the worst the world has to offer young women. The ending is as satisfying as it is unexpected. This reader can only hope that Russo Morin is planning a sequel.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 5, 2019
reviews.reviewText: Fact and fiction come together to tell the upstairs -downstairs stories of Ginevra, a young Italian immigrant girl, and Pearl, the debutante daughter, as they come of age at the turn of the 20th century in the glittering splendor of Newport. It's a good story that held my interest, though the writing could have been stronger and It definitely needed a good copy editor. Living in Rhode Island not far from Newport, I appreciated that the description, geography, and history of time, place, and prominent families were accurate. The two main characters and their families were fictional, as were the murder and trial depicted in the novel; however, Tessie Oehlrich, Mamie Fish, and Alva and Consuelo Vanderbilt (and others who appear) were very real, as was the society depicted by the author. Ms. Morin lives in Newport, and it shows, based on the level of authenticity demonstrated. I had pictured "The Beeches" as The Elms, and indeed, The author states she used it as the model for Pearl's family's cottage. The proofreading and copy editing, however, were sorely needed. There was WAY too much repetition of hackneyed and pseudo-foreshadowing phrases along the lines of, "It would be the first time, but not the last," " I would remember this moment forever, " and "If only I had," usually appearing at the end of a chapter. There were also too many words misused and sentence fragments; I'm not sure if this came from the digitization, or whether the novel was self-published, or just sloppiness or laziness. But c'mon - the SPROUTING Rock Bathing Association - one error that particularly sticks in my mind. Overall a good read, but I do wish more care had been taken with its execution.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 17, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Free on kindle unlimited
reviews.reviewText: This book is much more enjoyable if you have been to the Summer Cottages in Rhode Island. I have a few times and highly recommend the tours. I found this a fun read.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 6, 2018
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars beautifully written by Donna Russo
reviews.reviewText: Gilded Summers, beautifully written by Donna Russo, perfectly captures the dichotomy and similarity of women in the Guilded Age in Newport, Rhode Island. Pearl and Ginevra, seemingly so distant in terms of their upbringing, social status and life circumstance, discover that they both yearn for a life determined by their own passions, not the confines of their birthright. The unlikely, yet heartwarming bond between servant and debutant shatters the notion that social status defines or limits deep friendship. Theirs is a story of defiance, determination, passion and self truth. WIth the glorious coastal location set amid spectacular and lavish "summer cottages", the author's gift of stunning description captures the essence of beautiful Newport. Those familiar with the area will deeply appreciate the historical information of Newport woven into the pages. In this era of celebrating and recognizing strength in women, Gilded Summers, and author Russo, remind us that this strength, though overshadowed in years past, has been a driving force throughout the ages.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 21, 2020
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Friendship in a time of Servants
reviews.reviewText: Ginevra and Pearl were not meant to be friends. Pearl was of high society and Ginevra was the seamstress. That didn't stop these two. They met in Newport every summer and they met in secret. They formed a bond of friendship that most didn't know in the late 1800s.This book surprised me with it's wit, humor, and female friendship that developed before my eyes. I couldn't put it down from the moment I picked it up. I can't wait to read the next one.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 22, 2020
reviews.reviewText: A portrait of the gilded age approached from a somewhat different point of view. The story of two women; one a scion and one a servant. True friends, and sisters under the skin, experience what it means to be women at the dawning of the 20th century when women’s roles were changing, and the fabric of the gilded age was being to tatter.Looking forward to the next book...

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on July 9, 2020
reviews.reviewText: A gift to my wife, who thoroughly enjoyed the book.

reviews.reviewTitle: Fesselnd, spannend von Anfang bis Ende
reviews.reviewText: Eine wahre Freude in diese Zeit zurück versetzt zu werden.Super Story, historisch, feministisch, fashionable und unterhaltend. Emotional packend bis zum Schluss!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 24, 2021
reviews.reviewText: This could be a good book if the author had taken even a tiny bit of trouble understanding the period she is writing about. From a number of absurd statements, such as on poor Italian villagers starting their days with espresso in the 1890s to the modern views on accents and diversity, to how big houses were run in the 1890s to the underlying modern premise of women empowerment during the period described, the book is fool of anachronisms. I can see the same story working much better if positioned 80 years later in time.

reviews.reviewTitle: A really good read, especially if you know Newport , Rhode Island and the history of the mansions.
reviews.reviewText: There were many things I liked about this book. Th introduction of each section headed by the name of one the two main characters helped the reader keep track of who was narrating the events. The character development, plot, descriptions and sequence of storyline was well done. The intrigue of the upper classes and the ‘gossipy’ aspects of their shenanigans were entertaining and engaging. Actual historical issues of the day were woven into the story which added to its authenticity. The book stretched my imagination and made me wonder about what happened to the two main characters at the end, which was cleverly dubbed ‘the beginning’. A thoroughly good read.
